Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dissecting the Mechanisms of Genetic Control of Biological Systems via High-Dimensional Sparse Graphical Models

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the completion of genome sequencing projects for various organisms including human and other model organisms, the fundamental goal of research in computational genomics, systems biology, and genetics has been to gain a complete understanding of how the instruction sets encoded in genomes get executed within a cell system and organism. The recent advances in the high-throughput technology and next-generation sequencing technology have allowed the researchers to collect a large amount of data for the genomes and various other aspects of a cell system. Such datasets hold the key to understanding the detailed mechanisms of the genetic control of a biological system and further deepening our knowledge of cell biology with the potential for broad application. This project will develop statistical machine learning methods based on high-dimensional sparse graphical models for integrative analysis of genomic datasets. As graphical models provide a powerful tool for representing the complex structure of the unknown biological processes that underlie the observed genomic data, the computational methods to be developed in this project will be able to extract rich information on the genetic control of gene regulation systems from genome-scale datasets.

This project will also include training the next-generation computational biologists by supervising graduate students and incorporating the research results into the curriculum. The project will involve collaboration between computational scientists and biologists to participate in outreach programs for high-school students to present them an alternative career path that combines biological and computer sciences. In addition, the project will contribute to increasing womens participation in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To understand the biological processes behind complex diseases, biologists have been trying to uncover the pathways in gene regulatory networks that lead to the observed disease traits. The commonly-used approach to building the network model has been to perform experimental perturbations, using a gene knockdown or genome-editing technique, to infer its effect on other gene expression and clinical phenotypes. Instead, in this research we treat naturally-occurring genetic variation among individuals within a population as a source of perturbation, to learn a disease gene regulatory network that can be queried to understand how it is perturbed by each individual’s unique genotype, and how it in turn affects the clinical phenotypes.

Intellectual Merits: We developed a computational framework to model and learn the gene regulatory and phenotype networks and at the same time to identify the effects of the genetic variation on gene expression and phenotypes. We developed a computational model for representing the gene network perturbed by SNPs and an extremely fast algorithm for learning our model from genome-wide data with hundreds of thousands to millions of genotype variants on a desktop computer within several hours. We demonstrated our method on data from the Childhood Asthma Management Program. We found gene modules within our learned network model that mediate the effect from asthma-linked genetic variants to asthma-related clinical traits.

Broader Impact: The proposed research contributed to the knowledge of both statistical machine learning and biology. In statistical machine learning, it broadened the understanding of the classical problem of sparse regression estimation by considering it from the new perspective of learning a sparse graphical model that has a significantly greater expressive power for knowledge representation and thus, opened up doors to more complex regression-based learning methods. In genetics, it bridged the methodological gap between genome-wide association analysis and gene regulatory network analysis, and provided efficient computational tools for identifying both gene regulatory networks and genetic variants perturbing these networks simultaneously. In medicine, it provided significantly more powerful tools for unravelling the genetic basis of diseases and key molecular targets for treatment.

The PI was also involved in various educational activities to disseminate the results from the research activity. These educational outreach activities included a collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University’s Center for Talented Youth to host a program in Family Academic Programs Science and Technology Series at Carnegie Mellon University for students in elementary and middle schools, a tutorial presentation at the conference GLBIO, and leading a group of undergraduate students for a research project in OurCS workshop at Carnegie Mellon University.
